title: How to Allow 3rd Party Cookies on a Mac

steps.title: Open Safari.
steps.content: Open Safari. Click the Safari app icon, which resembles a blue compass, in your Mac's Dock. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Safari.
steps.content: Click Safari . It's a menu item in the top-left corner of the screen next to the Apple icon.

steps.title: Click Preferences….
steps.content: Click Preferences… . This option is near the top of the drop-down menu. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Privacy tab.
steps.content: Click the Privacy tab. It's at the top of the Preferences window. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Deselect the “Block All Cookies” option.
steps.content: Deselect the “Block All Cookies” option. This option is below the "Cookies and website data" heading. Doing so will enable cookies in your Safari browser. [4] X Research source You can also check a less liberal option, such as "Allow from websites I visit", to cut down on the number of third-party cookies on your computer. These cookies will make your browsing experience easier. They allow the 3rd-party elements (like ads and images) to remember your site preferences and give you locally relevant information.

steps.title: Open Chrome.
steps.content: Open Chrome. To do this, click the app icon, which looks like a red, yellow, and green orb surrounding a blue center.

steps.title: Click ⋮.
steps.content: Click ⋮ . This three-dot menu that you'll find in the top right corner of your browser opens the Chrome menu. [5] X Research source Cookies are enabled by default in Chrome. You won't have to turn them on unless you disabled them in the past.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings . It's usually near the bottom of the menu. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click Site Settings.
steps.content: Click Site Settings . You'll find this option under the "Privacy and security" heading in the panel on the right side of the window. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Click Cookies and site data.
steps.content: Click Cookies and site data . This is the first option under the "Content" header in the panel on the right side of the window. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Select which cookies you want to allow.
steps.content: Select which cookies you want to allow. You have three options for enabling cookies: [9] X Research source To allow all cookies, including those meant to track your browsing on other websites, select Allow all cookies . To allow all cookies except tracking cookies from third parties, select Block third-party cookies . This option may break some features on websites, but it will protect your privacy from trackers. To only block third-party cookies in Incognito mode , select Block third-party cookies in Incognito . This allows all cookies except when you open a new Incognito window.

steps.title: Adjust your cookie preferences for specific sites.
steps.content: Adjust your cookie preferences for specific sites. The "See all cookies and data" section allows you to specify cookie settings by website. In most cases, you won't need to adjust this setting, but if you'd like to choose which sites can always use cookies, can never use cookies, or which sites' cookies should be deleted upon closing Chrome, click Add to add a website now. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Open Firefox.
steps.content: Open Firefox. The app icon looks like an orange fox wrapped around a purple globe on your Launchpad or in the Dock. Cookies are enabled by default in Firefox. You won't have to turn them on unless you disabled them in the past.

steps.title: Open your Firefox Settings.
steps.content: Open your Firefox Settings. Click Firefox in the menu bar at the top of the screen, and then click Preferences . [11] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Privacy & Security tab.
steps.content: Click the Privacy & Security tab. You'll find this tab on the left side of the page. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Select a level of tracking protection.
steps.content: Select a level of tracking protection. Firefox allows you to choose from three different cookie modes: [13] X Research source Standard: This option allows all cookies except for those that track you on other websites, although it will let some cross-site trackers through if they are for login or other non-predatory reasons. This option is best for most users. Strict: This option is similar to Standard, except it blocks all third-party cookies. This could make it difficult to log in to some websites and use certain website features. Custom: This option lets you choose exactly which types of cookies you want to allow and block. This option is great for power users who are familiar with different types of tracking cookies. Cookies will make your browsing experience easier. They allow the 3rd-party elements (like ads and images) to remember your site preferences and give you locally relevant information.
